Question:
What does this do?

https://google.github.io/googletest/reference/matchers.html
matctches any.
Replied and Addressed the comments. Thanks
We should get this add to phosphor-dbus-interfaces, right?
I am not sure where we will model this? This is just a piece of path.
We should be able to have the primary BMC path added, similar to how we have the namespace now.
Done
Would this be more readable as a switch instead of if-tree?
Done
Just return it?
Done
Just "TYPE".
nit: spelling
Done
Done
This sounds like `debug`?  Seems a little chatty to leave in the final code.
Already removed this by returning within switch case itself.
I suspect you want to add `skipSignal = true` parameter to all of these set calls in this function.
Done
Probably want minValue = 0 here?
Done

Isn't this sufficient?

```
const auto& thresholdStr = validThresholds[type];
```

This is a minor optimization that you might consider (only so that we don't have to get the string except in the boundary conditions):

```
auto thresholdStr = [=]() -> const auto& { return validThresholds[type]; };
```

Really, I don't think you even need any of this though...

`sdbusplus::message::convert_to_string(type)` gives you what you want.
Done
I changed the code around to make it more clear.
Why would we have a non-finite threshold?  This seems like a configuration problem.
Yes, i suppose there could be a Nan value or something, isn't it better to safeguard around it or better let it fail?
Can we leave some comments as to what we're safeguarding against?  It seems strange to me that the threshold can be NaN.  Why wouldn't we just leave that threshold out of the config in that case?

Moved this check to the config parsing and threw an exception there -
std::invalid_argument("Invalid threshold value");

Reduce the `asserted()` call by using if-initializer syntax.
```
if (auto asserted = ThresholdIntf::asserted(); asserted.contains(threshold))
```
Done

Save this `find` call with a if-initializer too.

Why use `find(...)->second` and not `[]`?

> Why use `find(...)->second` and not `[]`?

It fails with error -

../health_metric.cpp:139:59: error: passing 'const phosphor::health::metric::config::Threshold::map_t' {aka 'const std::map<std::tuple<sdbusplus::common::xyz::openbmc_project::common::Threshold::Type, sdbusplus::common::xyz::openbmc_project::common::Threshold::Bound>, phosphor::health::metric::config::Threshold>'} as 'this' argument discards qualifiers [-fpermissive]
  139 |                 auto tConfig = config.thresholds[threshold];
      |                                                           ^
As per our discussion, changed this to use ".at()".
METRIC
Done
METRIC
Done
This seems strange.  Why not do a loop in the code and check all the thresholds at once?  What about the other threshold types?  Why don't we allow HardShutdown, for example?

We start from Critical and walk our way back to lower levels.

I have added other ones too now. Please check.
Done

Seeing these get<0> and get<1> here lead me to wonder what `value_t` even is and leaving the comment in the .hpp file.

`value.foo` and `value.bar` would make this code more obvious than `get<N>`.

Already added a comment in the .hpp file.
Done

Not sure we should emit a warning every time like this.  Means we're going to emit `windowSize` warnings at the beginning of the process every time.  Maybe we should do it only when we are at 0?

This isn't really a warning is it?  Seems like debug and/or info at the maximum.
Done
METRIC
Done

Would prefer you explicitly add `paths_t` to line 29 rather than polluting the whole namespace in the header file.

`using phosphor::health::utils::path_t;`.
Done

Do you think we should copy the HealthMetric into this object?  Or can we just preserve the pieces of it we immediately need?  I'm a little uncomfortable with holding a reference to it, partially because I had to look through 3 different commits / classes to figure out how it all chains together.

It seems to me that once the top-level creates all of its children from the config we could drop the top-level instance (of config) to free up the memory.
Done

Since `create` calls `setProperties` which sets properties (all as part of the construction) you need to pass the constructor here with the `action::defer_emit` here and then sometime after you're done setting up the object you need to call this->emit_object_added.

Otherwise, you're going to be emitting signals for all those initialization implying that the values changed.
Done
I have absolutely no idea why idea why `value_t` is a tuple of two doubles.  What do these represent?  (please add comments at a minimum, maybe a real struct?)
Done, added comment.
I don't see any usage of this function and the doxygen is pretty terse so it is a little hard to review for correct functionality.
This will get used in the test and health_monitor.cpp, so i added it early to get the paths for the bmc inventory item.
Moved to the collection interface patch.
Done
Is this useful?

Changed it for better.
Done
return {};
Why an empty vector? Don't we need to return paths?
The variable is no longer used because you've created a local one on line 39.  `return {};` here is all you need.
Done
unmocked? 😊
I think you should generally favor `new_bus` and not `new_default`.
Done
Done

Why are we getting a service name from the interface name?

I'd rather something obviously testing related here.
Done
I'm not sure this is necessary.  This stuff is created by the bindings.  Why add an explicit test for it?
Done
This is an invalid test.  We should _not_ be emitting signals as part of constructing an object (I alluded to this in the code itself).
Done
I'm not sure you have to test these, but fine if you want to leave it in place.
Keeping them for now.
It's fine to use the mock stuff.  You could have also added a separate `context` to be a dbus client.
Using mock for now.

Thanks for the review. Addressed your comments.
